body:
No tests yet just wanted to get this up to see if this sort of implementation looks good. (See [this comment below](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/18161#issuecomment-1101435066) for a demo screencap.)

Docs can probably be improved, basically just copy-pasted the `vim.ui.select` docs and made the necessary changes.

See #17044

comment_regular_data.body:
How will that look for the user?
Does he just have to input the numbers he want?
(perhaps send a screen record)

>  (perhaps send a screen record)

Yeah, thought about doing that originally, probably should've  

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46855713/163819693-8e5100ec-ff70-4a1c-9c72-58ba6410c4ec.mov

>  basically just copy-pasted the vim.ui.select docs and made the necessary changes.

Isn't that a sign that maybe this should be a parameter rather than a separate function?

In vscode, it's just a parameter, `canPickMany`: https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#window.showQuickPick

> Isn't that a sign that maybe this should be a parameter rather than a separate function?
> 
> 
> 
> In vscode, it's just a parameter, `canPickMany`: https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#window.showQuickPick


This was originally what I did, via a `multiple_select` (name TBD) option to `select`, but the thought was this could be problematic? [From @mfussenegger in the Neovim Dev matrix room](https://matrix.to/#/!ixkiMdeKnoXIanEVeZ%3Amatrix.org/%24h2RIUlQzPCUC84YCq22d7ebJUPYgfdR2_ErtFa8t_K8):

> I think it will have to be a vim.ui.select_many. Using new options will be problematic because external extensions may not support those, and I think in this case it will also affect the return value (or rather callback argument)

So I just went with that, but perhaps it could just be made an option.

> I think it will have to be a vim.ui.select_many. Using new options will be problematic because external extensions may not support those, 

Wait... what? We must not add bad interfaces just to support extensions that can't deal with possibly new parameters. Extensions must be able to handle that.

If our extensibility model ever promised that we wouldn't add new parameters or behaviors, that's insane and broken.

> > I think it will have to be a vim.ui.select_many. Using new options will be problematic because external extensions may not support those,
> 
> Wait... what? We must not add bad interfaces just to support extensions that can't deal with possibly new parameters. Extensions must be able to handle that.
> 
> If our extensibility model ever promised that we wouldn't add new parameters or behaviors, that's insane and broken.

`vim.ui.select` was added with the intention of being overridden by plugins. We have to consider that those implementations may not support new parameters immediately.

If we add a `pick_many` option (or whatever it will be called), plugin A could use this new option and would expect a list of value instead of a value as result. If a user also uses plugin B which overrides `vim.ui.select` but doesn't support this new option yet, plugin A would break because it receives an unexpected result.

I guess plugin A could handle the case that the implementation may not support this new option, but I am not sure if people will account for that. Maybe pointing it out in the docs would be good enough as well?

The other reason I proposed to add a new function is that I am not a fan of functions which return different types/shapes based on an argument - maybe because in a static typed language with strict type system it usually makes for a clunky API because you cannot express this relationship between argument value and result type with most type systems. (And even if more ergonomic/feasible in a dynamic language, I find it can be confusing). I guess this is personal preference and I won't object if you/others disagree.

> not a fan of functions which return different types/shapes based on an argument

Fair point, but that's why select() should have returned a list or a structure from the start. "one" or "many" is not an important distinction. "one" is just a list of one thing.

For these "vim.ui" interfaces, we should probably always return structures. Especially because they are intended to be extensible.

# Proposal

1.  ~~Add a **new argument** that is passed to  `on_choice`~~
    - ~~this is backwards-compatible~~
    - ~~the old first argument is deprecated~~
    - ~~the new argument is always a list of zero or more selected items~~
1.  **Breaking change** to `on_choice`: always return a list of zero or more choices.

Not sure I understand what advantages there are to having a single function and an additional parameter opposed to two functions.

From an implementation perspective it looks as if it boils down to:

```
if param then
  ... multi_select_code
else
  ... single_select_code
```

From a usage perspective, generalizing the result to a list means that users who want to use the select _one_ functionality will always have to write boilerplate like `if choice and #choice == 1 then .. choice[1]`.
Distinguishing the two uses by having a `[a] -> Maybe a` function and a `[a] -> [a]` function seems a lot more convenient from a usage point of view. (And if there were strong types, it would be less error prone)

I in general get the appeal to find a design that allows to cover multiple cases the same way, but I fail to see the advantages in this case.

> Not sure I understand what advantages there are to having a single function and an additional parameter opposed to two functions.

The documentation and interface are almost identical. Having large amounts of nearly-identical docs and APIs is a maintenance burden, and cognitive burden on users and reduces discoverability.

> From a usage perspective, generalizing the result to a list means that users who want to use the select _one_ functionality will always have to write boilerplate like `if choice and #choice == 1 then .. choice[1]`.

`choice` will never be `nil`, it would always be an empty list. Lua's `next()` function also can be useful: `if next(choice) then`. Providing an example that uses `next()` in the docstring, helps users. Providing special-case interfaces, hurts users by (1) increasing the surface-area of the API and (2) losing an opportunity to show composition and best practices.

If common tasks involving tables/lists/maps are verbose boilerplate, we we need to add more tools to `vim.*`. Things like `vim.first()`, `vim.last()`, etc. could make sense. The solution is not to have special variants of our interfaces.

In general we should focus on making tables/lists/maps easy to work with.

> choice will never be nil, it would always be an empty list. 

If the list is a new parameter to stay backward compatible that is unfortunately not possible. Given that the plugins which can override it are not bound to the neovim release cycle there is also no version check, so plugins will have to check both args if they want to be forward & backward compatible.

I'd make a different judgement call in this case but I don't have any other arguments either, so I concede.

> plugins will have to check both args if they want to be forward & backward compatible.

Yep. I'm strongly leaning towards just making a breaking change here: `choice` is always a list.

1. `vim.ui` is a new territory and we're still figuring out best practices here. 
2. We don't guarantee an API contract in Lua userland until Nvim 1.0.
    - RPC `:help api-contract` is a strong contract because of the nature of RPC clients.
3. Doubt there are too many plugins extending `vim.ui`. We can manually notify them.
4. We can backport the breaking change to 0.7.1
    - We did something similar for the LSP client, we made breaking changes last year.
Hello @justinmk @smolck. What is the state of this enhancement?
